body:
Great work.

I admittedly don't understand it all, so someone on the electron team would be a better reviewer when you upstream.  You might get some pushback on adding tests for this if it's not already covered by existing tests they have. 

I'm good for you to merge here for now though and just modify the commit(s) or do a new comment with changes they suggest upstream.
@bbondy
great!
@bbondy
sweet!
@bbondy
@bbondy
Please have all Brave commits rebased on top of the Electron ones.
++ thanks for re-organizing this.
fixes https://github.com/brave/browser-laptop/issues/412
++ merging

Nit: "dispostion" typo in comment.

Great to have this. Is there another issue on file to clean up at a higher level, so the code doesn't have extra tests that seem to mix concerns and layers? Thanks.

It's actually not too terrible. "AttachGuest" is attaching the browser plugin so flipping the visibility there isn't great, but it's not the worst thing in the world. I haven't tried it yet with a fresh build of libchromiumcontent, but another possible reason this is happening is because all the tabs have the same "embedder" and it is visible even when the guest will not be. I'm definitely going to look into more to verify the underlying issue now that the immediate problem is solved.
Thanks for doing this over the weekend. Merging.
This looks great, merging.
merging!
Looking great, nice work on all oft his.
Can this be upstreamed to atom/electron instead? Then we can get it on our next version bump.
Looks good. Great work on all of this!
oh my bad, thanks, I'll merge.  I probably added it a long time ago and forgot :)
Thanks for the fix!
Can you submit this and #10 to Electron itself?

Absolutely @paulcbetts, but this needs a small change first. We temporarily worked around this issue in the browser-laptop code, but right now content scripts enabled on renderer start will stay enabled for all pages even if you change them based on url. We will fix this by adding content matching rules like the chrome webview tag, but for now I can pull out the ShouldFork changes related to the work we did for window.opener and create a new PR for Electron.
I could also leave out content scripts entirely for now and come back with another PR when they are ready for general use
@bridiver That'd be awesome! What's the difference between content scripts and preload scripts - is it just the node integration aspect?

Yea, the content scripts still have access to ipcRenderer send, sendSync, sendToHost and webFrame api methods, but the functions are bound to plain v8 objects and they are removed from the global context before the page gets access to the script context. I wanted to keep the functionality without breaking existing node-based preload scripts
fixes https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/3009
Oh amazing, I was wanting to get to this, thanks for taking!
